VI.  PROGRAM BENEFITS, IMPACT, ASSUMPTIONS, AND RISKS 
A.  Program Benefits 
130.  The PGEIP is expected to yield significant benefits to the people of Punjab, specifically 
the following:  
 
(i)  More  efficient  allocation  of  public  resources. By integrating planning and 
budgeting  processes,  the  Program  will  ensure  greater  cohesion  between 
development priorities and fiscal policy formulation. The adoption of the MTEF 
will  make  budgeting  more  transparent  and  predictable,  and  the  infusion  of 
performance orientation will strengthen fiscal discipline and accountability in the 
use of public resources. All these intermediate outcomes will result in improved 
delivery of public services. 
 
(ii)  Greater financial sustainability of the pension system. The Punjab has made 
pioneering  efforts  in  this  direction.  Recognizing  the  significant  liabilities,  the 
provincial government is committed to accelerating funding. The move will boost 
civil  service  morale  by  ensuring  retirement  income  security,  ease  contingent

31
liability  management,  and  create  considerable  fiscal  space  for  pro-poor 
expenditures. Longer-term benefits include the promotion of private saving and 
asset  accumulation,  which  will  in  turn  contribute  to  the  province’s  economic 
growth, and to financial and private sector development. 
 
(iii)  An  efficient  and  effective  civil  service.  Improved  human  resource 
management in the civil service will increase value for money for the province. 
Efficient institutional structures, faster business procedures, and improved skills 
and capacity in the public sector will result in efficiency gains and improved 
productivity in the public sector, with consequent benefits in service delivery and 
private sector development.  
 
(iv)  A dynamic private sector. A coherent private sector development strategy, an 
improved regulatory framework, reduced government participation in the private 
sector, and greater compliance with international standards will facilitate private 
sector participation and result in greater efficiency and higher investment and 
growth  rates.  Likewise,  a  robust  public-private  partnership  framework  will 
mobilize  resources  toward  more  and  better-quality  infrastructure  and  social 
services. 
 
131.  All the benefits will contribute to employment creation, broad-based economic growth, 
social  development,  and  poverty  reduction.  These  are  important  building  blocks  toward 
achieving the long-term goals outlined in Vision 2020 of significantly raising the living standards 
in the Punjab.  
 
B.  Program Impact 
132.  Economic and Poverty Impact. The Program is expected to create significant positive 
economic  impact  in  the  medium  to  long  term.  Improved  public  financial  management  will 
improve efficiency, increase value for money of public spending, and generate resources for 
investment and development spending. The establishment of the PPF and GPIF will directly 
contribute to investment and economic growth. The efficiency gains achieved through civil 
service reforms and private sector development will further lead to productivity growth, and thus 
sustainable  economic  growth.  The  Program  will  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  through 
economic  growth.  It  will  also  directly  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  through  resources 
generated for social and development spending, and through a more effective public sector that 
is geared toward service delivery outcomes. 
     
133.  Institutional Impact. The PGEIP will contribute to institutional enhancement. Increased 
coordination between planning and budgeting will promote a more holistic approach to public 
expenditure  management,  with  significant  gains  in  terms  of  output-oriented  financial 
management. The establishment of a professionally managed PPF and GPF will represent a 
key milestone, and could potentially serve as a catalytic model for similar reforms at the federal 
level  and  in  other  provinces.  Civil  service  reforms  will  bring  across-the-board  institutional 
development in the public sector. Efforts to promote private sector development, such as the 
establishment of the PPP cell, will strengthen the interface between the public and private 
sectors.  
 
134.  Social Impact. The beneficial social impact of the PGEIP can arise from the following 
factors. First of all, the introduction of more efficient public resource management practices 
throughout  government  will  gradually  contribute  to  improvements  in  the  quality  of  service

32  
delivery, especially in key social sectors. Second, the improved pension system will strengthen 
the social safety net. Lastly, the improved quality of life through higher economic and income 
growth will have an overall and direct impact on social outcomes. The detailed poverty reduction 
and social strategy of the Program is in Appendix 13. 
 
135.  Resettlement, Indigenous People, and the Environment. The PGEIP will cause no 
direct or indirect involuntary resettlement, and will not lead to any issues affecting indigenous 
peoples (category C). The PGEIP is also unlikely to have any adverse environmental impact 
(category C). 
 
C.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
136.  The realization of the benefits and impact of the PGEIP depends on a number of 
assumptions and are subject to a variety of risks. Mitigating measures have accordingly been 
integrated into the design of the Program. 
 
137.  Political Risks. Pakistan is in an election year and any political changes could have 
major administrative consequences. The caretaker setup expected to be in place later in 2007 
may not have the appetite for long-gestation reforms. However, the risk of reversing the broad 
directions of reforms is low, given the present broad consensus on reforms among the major 
political players. The flexibility built into the single-tranche operations is also well suited to 
addressing the uncertainty arising in this context, as specific reform actions can be adjusted to 
reflect changes in the political environment.  
 
138.  Governance Risks. Reforms could be undermined or delayed by vested interests that 
are threatened by greater transparency and accountability. However, strong ownership and 
support  at  the  highest  political  and  bureaucratic  levels,  coupled  with  gradually  improving 
incentives for better performance, will help mitigate this risk. The PDF that began in 2003 has 
institutionalized broad-based stakeholder participation, and the PGEIP design has been defined 
through this participative process.  
 
139.  Implementation Risks. Insufficient capacity within the GoPb to handle the envisaged 
reforms could impede implementation. However, with the help of the TA loan under the PRMP, 
and by adopting effective procurement options and hiring the Singapore Civil Service College, 
the PMU and departments have been able to overcome capacity limitations. Enhancing IA 
ownership of the Program is also a key method of mitigating implementation risks.  
 
140.  External  and  Macroeconomic  Risks.  Despite  uncertainty  in  the  geopolitical 
environment, the external environment in recent years has been largely favorable to Pakistan 
and the country has had strong macroeconomic indicators in the past 5 years. However, while 
structural reforms are beginning to show positive results, poverty levels and inequality remain 
high and must be reduced. The widening trade imbalance and current account deficit, insecurity 
in the region, and the cost of earthquake reconstruction accentuate the macroeconomic risks. 
Some of the risks are beyond the control of the federal Government and the GoPb, but prudent 
economic  management  strategies  can  mitigate  macroeconomic  vulnerability.  Significant 
increases in the expenditure allocations for the social sectors and direct poverty reduction 
measures will lead to higher poverty reduction impact.

I.  Achievements of the Punjab in the Punjab Resource Management Program and

1.  Punjab  Resource  Management  Program.  Enhancing  the  effectiveness  of  public 
financial management in the Punjab has been the principal objective of the Punjab Resource 
Management Program (PRMP). Under subprogram (SP) 1 of PRMP (covering reforms over 
January 2003–June 2005), the government of the Punjab (GoPb) launched and implemented a 
range of key reform measures focused on fiscal restructuring to boost revenue generation and 
expenditure rationalization, and private sector development. Under SP2 of PRMP (July 2005–
June 2007) the government carried forward the reforms focusing on (i) creating fiscal space, (ii) 
improving efficiency and transparency in the allocation and use of funds, (iii) increasing the pro-
poor impact of public spending and service delivery, and (iv) creating an enabling environment 
for private sector development. 
 
2.  Creating fiscal space was a major objective of the PRMP. Measures to enhance revenue 
mobilization included the rationalization of the tax structure, and analytical work in preparation 
for the reorganization of the Excise and Taxation Department to increase efficiency in tax 
collection.  Rationalization  of  expenditure  was  achieved  primarily  through  the  reduction  of 
interest payments by swapping high-interest cash development loans (CDLs) from the federal 
Government  with  less-costly  borrowings  from  international  donors.  During  the  PRMP, 
$300 million  in  CDLs  was  retired  by  the  provincial  government.  The  introduction  of  a 
medium-term framework in fiscal planning and budgeting represents a key achievement under 
the PRMP. The Finance Department (FD) prepared the first medium-term budget framework 
(MTBF) in fiscal year (FY) 2004, which included 3-year annual rolling estimates of the main 
categories of revenues and expenditures. The Planning and Development Department (P&DD) 
prepared a medium-term development framework (MTDF) for the first time in FY2006.   
 
3.  Civil service reforms under the PRMP emphasized capacity building of civil servants, 
especially through international exposure for senior public servants. A training relationship has 
been established with the Singapore Civil Service College. A civil service census of provincial 
government has been pilot-tested in one district government. A number of measures were also 
taken  to  facilitate  private  sector  development,  including  (i)  pilot-testing  of  public-private 
partnership models in the health sector, (ii) completion of an assessment of the provincial policy 
environment  and  cost  of  doing  business,  and  (iii)  strengthening  of  property  rights  though 
improved land titling.  
 
4.  By taking a holistic approach to a wide range of reform areas, the PRMP has laid a firm 
basis for public resource management reforms in the Punjab. Strengthening public resource 
management, however, is a complex and gradual process that requires long-term commitment. 
The devolution process has also brought about new challenges that require realignment of 
power and responsibilities between the provincial and local governments. Building on the reform 
outcomes over 2003–2007, the GoPb now wishes to undertake a range of second-generation 
reforms to deal effectively with the challenges it faces. 
 
5.  Achievements of Punjab Devolved Social Services Program. Pakistan introduced 
sweeping devolution reforms in 2001. A key objective underpinning devolution is improved 
social  service  delivery.  Poor  social  service  delivery,  and  the  resultant  lack  of  human 
development, has been a major cause of poverty. Devolution was intended to significantly

enhance service delivery by bringing service providers and governments closer to citizens than 
they had been under a centralized system. The loans for the Punjab Devolved Social Services 
Program (PDSSP) 1 were designed within this broad context. The program was approved on 
20 December 2004, and the first tranche was released on 26 December 2005. The release of 
the second tranche is currently under consideration.  
 
6.  PDSSP is a multi-sector and multidimensional governance reform program. It seeks to 
strengthen devolved social services for more equitable, efficient, effective, and sustainable 
delivery of social services in line with Punjab Local Government Ordinance (PLGO) 2001. It 
addresses governance, financing, and technical constraints on devolved service delivery in the 
health, education, special education, and water supply and sanitation sectors. Reforms under 
PDSSP seek three principal policy outcomes:  
 
(i)  realigning intergovernmental relations to support devolved social services, 
(ii)  rationalizing and setting minimum standards for social services, and  
(iii)  strengthening  public  accountability  mechanisms  and  promoting  public-private 
partnerships.  
 
7.  Various initiatives have been implemented under the PDSSP. Some key achievements 
to date are highlighted below. 
 
8.  Articulating  and  Clarifying  Devolution.  Local  governments  initially  faced  huge 
problems in comprehending devolution. There was a lack of understanding about devolved 
financial and administrative powers. To facilitate the working of devolution and local government, 
a  compendium  of  local  government  laws,  rules,  and  regulations  has  been  prepared  and 
published by PDSSP. The document has been circulated free of cost to all local governments. It 
has effectively helped explain devolution to provincial and local governments.  
 
9.  Instituting Planning. Local government planning capacity was practically nonexistent 
before the implementation of the PDSSP. Under the PDSSP, local government planning has 
received  tremendous  impetus  from  the  annual  sector  planning  (ASP)  process.  Through 
intensive training, capacity building, and strong emphasis on ASP, the PDSSP has introduced 
guidelines for planning, initiated the annual planning process, and instituted planning practice at 
the local government level.  
 
10.  In addition to ASP, the PDSSP also supported strategic planning over the medium term. 
The medium-term development strategic directions for the four social sectors covered by the 
PDSSP have found fully expression in the development of the MTDF. The MTDF has also 
become a key instrument for linking expenditure with improvements in service delivery. 
 
11.  Bridging Financing Gaps and Introducing Rules-Based Resource Allocation. The 
PDSSP introduced the concept of resource allocation to local governments through conditional 
grants. These have made possible timely and assured transfers of funds to local governments in 
a transparent manner, helped to bridge financing gaps, assisted the local governments in 
improving social service delivery, and paved the way for introducing transparent rules-based 
resource allocation.

II.  Sector Analysis 
 
A.  Public Resource Management: A Conceptual Framework  
 
20.  Public resource management is the primary tool for a country’s economic management 
and public service delivery. Fiscal management and the quality of civil service are the two core 
elements of effective public resource management. Fiscal management consists of systems and 
procedures for medium-term planning and budgeting, as well as measures aimed at fiscal space 
creation  through  public  expenditure  management  and  revenue  generation  reform.  Public 
expenditure  management  tools  include  expenditure  compression,  rationalization,  and 
prioritization measures. Expenditure compression is aimed at reducing nonproductive spending 
(e.g., interest payments), while expenditure rationalization and prioritization include streamlining 
the current expenditure pattern to make it more efficient and aligned with the government’s 
development  priorities  (e.g.,  pension  reform,  salary  and  wage  reform,  and  divestment  of 
loss-making state-owned enterprises). Revenue-generation measures represent another tool for 
fiscal space creation. They consist mainly of initiatives to increase the revenue yield of taxes 
and fees raised by the government (e.g., tax policy and tax administration reform, and reform of 
user fees).  
 
21.  The quality of the civil service is the second main pillar of public resource management, 
as it critically affects government’s efficiency and effectiveness in attaining its fiscal policy goals, 
and  ultimately  its  responsiveness  to  citizens’  needs.  A  well-functioning  civil  service  would 
enable the government to attract and retain qualified and competent staff and to hold them 
accountable for results while benefiting the citizens through improved public service delivery.  
 
22.  Private sector development can also play a key role in enhancing the efficiency of public 
resource management by improving the revenue-generating capacity and enabling a more 
efficient allocation of resources across competing priorities. On the one hand, private sector–led 
growth would enlarge the tax base of the economy and increase the revenue yield. On the other 
hand, a dynamic and vibrant private sector would allow public sector disengagement from the 
provision of goods and services that do not justify public sector involvement. This would in turn 
create fiscal space for the provision of public service services and government spending in 
pro-poor sectors.

1.  Medium-Term Planning and Budgeting 
23.  A growing number of developing countries have adopted the medium-term expenditure 
framework (MTEF)4 to increase predictability in resource allocation, and to strengthen the links 
between policy, planning, and budgeting. Recent studies5 have highlighted the importance of a 
good macro-fiscal model and solid budget management and execution practices as two key 
enabling conditions for the successful implementation of MTEF.  
  
24.  Weak  Budget  Preparation  and  Execution  and  Poor  Performance  Orientation. 
Development expenditure is specifically related to investment in the development of physical or 
human resources through defined projects. In this sense it must be distinguished from the 
accounting distinction between current and capital expenditure. A development project may 
involve both recurrent and capital elements.  
 
25.  The recurrent budget refers to expenditures that are recurrent in nature and are further 
distinguished between regular and new expenditures. Budget submissions are made separately 
for the two expenditures, and priority in reviewing budget submissions is typically directed to the 
new expenditure. Regular expenditure is increased to reflect pay and price increases but is 
assumed to be necessary and not subject to in-depth scrutiny. New expenditure may arise as a 
result of a development project with recurrent expenditure implications. When the project is 
completed it is treated as new expenditure on the recurrent budget for a 3-year period before 
being absorbed into the regular budget if its continuation is still justified.6  
 
26.  The annual budget statement in its current format does not provide a transparent picture 
of the allocation of resources across sectors and spending categories. Expenditures are only 
aggregated  along  functional  classifications,  which  do  not  provide  information  about  the 
composition of expenditures as would be captured from the economic classification. In the 
annual budget statement there is no overall summary statement giving an overview of the 
government budget in terms of surplus or deficit.

completion. The recurrent budget submissions are received and adjusted by the Budget Wing of 
the  FD.7 There  are  no  formal  meetings  with  departments  to  negotiate  changes  in  the 
submissions, though informal contact may be made. In the case of development expenditure, 
the departmental submissions are examined in the P&DD. The BCC was updated in 2005/2006

2.  Civil Service Pension System 
43.  The GoPb is the largest employer in Pakistan, with about one million civil servants and 
about 388,000 pensioners (including retired employees, and spouses and eligible dependents of 
deceased employees). The pension system rests on two main pillars: the Punjab pension 
system  (PPS)  and  the  General  Provident  Fund  (GPF).  Membership  in  both  schemes  is 
mandatory. Since 2005, most civil servants have been hired on a contractual basis and are not 
entitled to PPS and GPF benefits, receiving instead a 30% salary premium. About 50,000 civil 
servants have been contractual employees since 2005.  
 
44.  The PPS is a noncontributory, unfunded defined-benefits system financed from current 
government revenues. The normal retirement age is 60, subject to the employee’s having 
completed 10 years of service. Individual benefit levels are determined by a formula that takes 
into account the final wage and the length of service. The replacement rate is capped at 70% (of 
the basic wage in the final year) for a worker with 30 years of service. Up to 35% of the pension 
can be commuted and taken as a lump sum, and the remainder is paid as an annuity until death. 
 
45.  The  GPF  is  an  employee-only  contributory  scheme.  Civil  servants  are  required  to 
contribute 3–8% of basic salary to the GPF, and the contributions are notionally housed in 
individual accounts. Aside from book entry, employee contributions are not kept separately, and 
are included in the provincial government’s consolidated accounts. Accumulated funds are not 
invested to meet pension obligations, which like the liabilities under the PPS, are financed 
through the general budget. The government determines the rate of return on employees’ GPF 
contributions each year, which is currently around 11%. Workers can borrow from their accounts 
up to age 50 for specific purposes such as illness and related travel, overseas travel related to a 
dependent’s education, marriages and funerals, and purchase of land, house, and vehicles. 
After age 50, members can borrow up to 60% of the balance without having to give a reason or 
pay back the advance. After age 55, an advance of up to 80% of the balance can be made, 
again with no need to repay the advance. Any remaining balance can be taken as a lump sum 
at the age of 60 or a year before retirement.

46.  Two other benefit schemes are available to the employees of the GoPb: the Benevolent 
Fund (BF) and the Central Employees Insurance Fund (CEIF). The BF covers all civil servants

47.  Unfunded Pension System. As highlighted above, both the PPS and the GPF are 
unfunded schemes financed through the provincial budget. Preliminary estimates indicate that 
the government’s pension liabilities could be as high as PRs400 billion. The outstanding GPF 
balance, including contributions and interest credited, is reported at PRs17 billion. Pension 
outlays  have  escalated  in  recent  years,  and  increased  from  PRs1.7  billion  in  FY1991  to 
PRs12.6 billion in FY2006. Interest payments on GPF balances have likewise increased sharply 
and  amounted  to  PRs4.5  billion  in  FY2006.  GPF  interest  payments  currently  exceed 
contribution, and the net outflow is projected to rise in the coming years. 
 
48.  The GoPb recognizes that its pension obligations have important implications for the 
finances  of  the  province,  and  that  pension  expenditures,  if  unchecked,  could  crowd  out 
investment in the infrastructure and social sectors. Urgent reforms are therefore needed to 
ensure the financial sustainability of the pension system, and to create the fiscal space for 
priority development expenditures.  
 
49.  Weak Record-Keeping, Administration , and Payment System.  In  its  payroll 
functions,  the  Office  of  the  Accountant  General,  Punjab  (AGP)  records  civil  servants’ 
employment data, including name, identification number, date of employment, wage history, and, 
as applicable, the date of retirement, termination of employment, or death. At retirement, the 
worker makes an application with the Office of the AGP, which calculates the worker’s benefits 
and creates a payment booklet. To collect the monthly benefit the pensioner (or dependent) 
must present the payment booklet to a designated payment agent at a branch of the National 
Bank of Pakistan (NBP).  
 
50.  An effective pension system requires: (i) a system for accurately recording employment 
history and employee contribution, and calculating benefits; and (ii) a system for ensuring timely 
payment of benefits to pensioners. The calculation of pension benefits is based on the length of 
service and final salaries. The calculation of GPF balances is relatively more complex, requiring 
information on (i) deductions of monthly contributions from payroll based on grades, (ii) crediting 
of  yearly  interest  on  the  balances,  and  (iii)  advances  against  balances  and  repayment  of 
advances.  The  system  of  record-keeping  and  benefit  calculations  in  the  Punjab  is  largely 
manual  and  paper-based.  The  absence  of  a  robust  record-keeping  and  management 
information  system,  combined  with  weak  accounting  and  actuarial  analysis  capacity,  has 
resulted in problems regarding the accuracy of pension entitlement calculation and individual 
payments. Cases of missing contributions, and therefore missing investment returns on the GPF, 
are common. There is no formal mechanism for a pensioner to initiate an inquiry or an appeals 
process when such omissions occur.  
 
51.  Pension disbursement through a designated branch of NBP is costly because of the 
cumbersome identification and entitlement verification processes. The payment agent identifies 
the retiree through the latter’s identification card and payment booklet, makes the payment, and 
records the payment in the payment booklet and on the form obtained from the Office of the 
AGP. A copy of the form is retained by the payment agent and another copy is routed to the 
Office of the AGP. The present system generates a payment notice to the authorized NBP

3.  Civil Service Reform 
58.  The public sector employs about 11% of employed workers in Punjab. This number 
includes about 967,000 in sanctioned posts in government departments and more than 100,000 
employees  in  the  123  public  sector  autonomous  bodies.  While  the  share  is  moderate,  it 
understates the importance of the public sector as a major formal sector employer, given that 
self-employment accounts for about 60% of total employment. The civil service wage bill and 
pensions account for about 59% of total consolidated recurrent expenditure. The need to reform 
the civil service has been felt both at the national and the provincial levels. Despite various 
attempts, the common perception is that the system remains similar to that inherited from 
Pakistan’s colonial  past.  A  recent  survey  by  Pakistan  Institute of Development  Economics 
indicates widespread negative perception and general discontent about public services, on the 
one hand, and disillusionment of civil servants themselves, on the other. Some of the main 
issues in the Punjab context are discussed below. 
 
59.  Weak  Recruitment,  Performance  Evaluation,  and  Promotion.  An  effective 
recruitment system is essential for ensuring the quality of entry of civil servants. In the Punjab, 
the recruitment of public servants for basic pay scale (BPS) 1712 and above is carried out by the 
Punjab Public Service Commission (PPSC). It is widely acknowledged that the commission 
faces  challenges  because  of  structural,  capacity,  and  procedural  constraints.  Similarly, 
performance evaluation has not served as an effective tool for performance monitoring. A large 
proportion of civil servants do not have job descriptions, let alone targets for achievement. The 
existing annual confidential report is commonly regarded as a compliance task and not useful as 
a record of performance evaluation. Further, in a system in which promotions are essentially 
based on seniority, performance evaluations play a limited role in career progression. The 
present cadre system also places more weight on recruiting senior management from the elite 
groups and not enough on seeking out management talent from specialist groups or from 
outside the civil service.  
 
60.  Uncompetitive Compensation and Benefits. There is substantial evidence that the 
real  compensation  gap  between  public  and  private  salaries  and  emoluments  has  steadily 
increased.  Moreover,  the  compensation  structure  of  wages  is  not  closely  linked  with 
performance and does not provide adequate incentives for good performance. The provincial 
government  has  no  control  over  civil  service  salary  scales,  which  are  set  by  the  federal 
Government.  It  can,  however,  create  contract  positions  outside  the  cadre  scales  or  pay 
additional allowances for specific positions. For example, program management units (PMUs) 
have been used as a device to create specific positions attracting higher reward. There is some 
evidence suggesting that the recruitment and remuneration practice of PMUs has strengthened 
performance  incentives.  PMUs  thus  should  be  seen  as  a  testing  case  and  precursor  for 
introducing performance-based human resource management in the civil service of the province.

major reform initiative since 2003 has been the shift toward contractual employment for new 
entrants into government service. Employees recruited on a contractual basis are paid an 
additional 30% of the minimum salary of the relevant pay scale as compensation for not being 
eligible  for  a  pension.  However,  the  difference  between  the  compensation  of  regular  and

4.  Private Sector Development 
68.  Private sector development is essential for the province to ensure job creation, economic 
development,  and  poverty  reduction.  The  private  sector  in  the  Punjab  is  dominated  by 
small-scale informal enterprises operating primarily in the services and manufacturing sector: 
97% of manufacturing units employ fewer than 10 people. Today, the small- and medium 
enterprise (SME) sector contributes 30% of national gross domestic product (GDP) and 35% of 
national  value  added  to  the  industrial  sector  and  generates  25%  of  manufacturing  export 
earnings.14 There are a number of impediments to the development of the SME sector. Most 
notable is the lack of access to financial resources, poorly developed property rights, low levels 
of human resource capacity, weak regulatory oversight, expensive but poor quality of public 
utilities, and weak marketing and transport linkages.  
 
69.  The labor force in 2002 numbered an estimated 27 million, 8.5% of these unemployed. 
The population of the Punjab is growing rapidly (3%), and the labor force is growing at a faster 
rate than the annual growth rate of new jobs registered (2.7%). The need to create new jobs, as 
a large number of young people enter the labor force, cannot be overestimated. While the 
agricultural  sector  will  continue  to  provide  the  bulk  of  employment  opportunities  for  the 
population, it is debatable whether it can provide full employment to substantial new additional 
labor. The bulk of employment opportunities have to be generated by the nonfarm sector.   
 
70.  Lack of Coherent Private Sector Development Strategy. The Punjab needs a good 
strategic framework to define the role of the state vis-à-vis the private sector. Although almost 
9 out of 10 Punjabis are already employed in the private sector, the reach of that sector in terms 
of contribution to provincial economy is only about 30%. The private sector requires support in 
addressing issues that have a public good element, impose positive or negative externalities on 
other businesses or the society, or have collective action issues. The state can help in this area 
by adopting a coherent private sector development (PSD) strategy and underwriting costs, and 
encouraging the development of collective solutions.  
 
71.  High Cost of Doing Business. In all recent surveys, the regulatory and compliance 
burdens for businesses in the Punjab still figure as major concerns. Financial and fiscal sector 
reforms have gone some way to reducing the cost of doing business. However, setting up the 
“rules of the game” and the regulatory framework remains the responsibility of the government, 
and reforms in this area need to be tackled urgently. To facilitate long-term engagement on this 
issue, the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP) foresees the GoPb 
instituting a regular survey on the cost of doing business in the province. The survey will (i) set 
benchmarks for performance, (ii) allow tracking of costs and of progress made, and (iii) allow 
regular and continuous engagement with the issues. It will identify the key problem areas and 
the government will introduce measures to implement the legal and institutional reforms needed

The Department for International Development (DFID) of the United Kingdom is supporting the government of the 
Punjab in the implementation of the Punjab Resource Management Program (PRMP) and has provided technical 
assistance (TA) of £5 million to be disbursed over a 3-year period until 2009. This support phase is ongoing and is 
focused on key PRMP intervention areas—public financial management, civil service reforms, and private sector 
development. Additional areas of support include reforming and building the capacity of the Bureau of Statistics (BOS) 
and the Punjab Economic Research Institute. An amount of £2 million has also been earmarked for the Policy 
Development Fund, to be used in response to requests from the government of the Punjab as the assistance unfolds 
and needs are identified. Coordination with the Asian Development Bank (ADB) TA for the PRMP is ensured through the 
executive and steering committees of the PRMP.  
The Government of Pakistan and the Government of the United Kingdom also signed recently a 10-year partnership 
agreement, whose purpose is to afford better predictability in development assistance and better alignment on key policy 
themes. The initial phase (until 2011) comprises a grant assistance package of £480 million, which is expected to take 
effect in April 2008. A substantial part of this assistance is meant for the province of Punjab. An initial assistance of £30 
million is being designed in collaboration with the Punjab to assist the 15 poorer districts in the province. The focus of 
assistance will be on alleviating poverty and improving social service delivery. On the back of the long-term partnership, 
the DFID is now working on evolving a more focused 10-year partnership with the government of the Punjab. The details 
of the partnership are yet to be finalized. The coordination between ADB and DFID under PRMP is a key to ensuring aid 
effectiveness.  
DFID Support for PRMP and PGEIP 
DFID is providing a parallel TA, amounting to £5 million, from 2006 to 2009 to support governance and public resource 
management reforms in the Punjab. The overall goal of the DFID assistance is to help the government move toward an 
accountable, efficient, and effective government that meets the needs of its people. Specifically, the following outputs 
are expected: (i) improved availability and quality of data, and economic and social research on the Punjab; (ii) more 
transparent and results-based budget allocations; (iii) public administrative reform, fully consistent with Punjab Local 
Government  Ordinance  (PLGO)  2001,  and  cognizant  of  the  current  and  future  human  resource  needs  of  the 
government; (iv) improved policies and capacity to support private sector development; (v) improved ability of the 
government of the Punjab to develop policy in areas complementary to the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement 
Program (PGEIP); and (vi) a communication strategy in place to widen ownership of pro-poor reforms. 
The TA grant is allocated as follows: Board of Statistics and Punjab Economic Research Institute, £1.3 million; public 
financial management, £0.5 million; private sector development, £0.5 million; civil service reforms, £0.5 million; and 
communication strategy, £0.2 million. In addition, a Policy Development Support Fund of £2 million can be used to 
respond to requests from the government for help in developing policy in important areas related to public financial 
management that were not covered by the previous PRMP. 
While  the  ADB  TA/program  and  the  DFID  grant  share  some  broad  common  areas,  including  public  financial 
management, civil service reforms, and private sector development, the possibility of overlap and duplication is small for 
a number of reasons. First, while the total DFID TA grant is £5 million, the allocation to the three common areas is only 
£1.5 million. Second, there are numerous issues in all the three common areas and the TA needs are large, reducing the 
possibility  of  duplication.  Third,  both  ADB  and  DFID  are  committed  to  achieving  donor  coordination  and  aid 
effectiveness. Thus, ADB and DFID will actively coordinate with each other to achieve complementarity of TA activities 
and outputs. For example, in the civil service area, DFID’s major area of assistance will be in developing a human 
resource management information database. Fourth and most importantly, the Planning and Development Department 
(P&DD) is the executing agency for both ADB and the DFID assistance, and the PRMP program management unit 
(PMU) is the overall program/TA management unit. The DFID TA will be implemented by a DFID-appointed TA 
management agency (TAMA), which will work with the government of the Punjab. The PRMP PMU will closely 
coordinate with the TAMA to ensure that the synergies between PGEIP and the DFID TA are maximized. Regular 
interaction between ADB, DFID, and the government will be maintained to improve coordination.

SUMMARY POVERTY REDUCTION AND SOCIAL STRATEGY  
 
A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis  
 
1.  In 2003, the government of the Punjab (GoPb) introduced the Punjab-Poverty Reduction 
Strategy Paper (P-PRSP) as its response to the steeply increasing incidence of poverty during 
the 1990s. The P-PRSP identified (i) governance reform, (ii) strengthening of planning capability, 
(iii)  improvements  in  service  delivery,  (iv)  fiscal  and  financial  reforms,  (v) income  and 
employment generation, and (vi) gender mainstreaming as key elements of effective poverty 
reduction in the Punjab. The Punjab Resource Management Program (PRMP) was aimed at 
supporting improvements in these areas. PRMP helped develop and operationalize the poverty-
focused investment strategies for six key sectors in order to implement the P-PRSP. It likewise 
supported  revenue  mobilization,  budgeting,  and  debt  management  reforms  to  create  fiscal 
space and improve the use of fiscal resources. This has set the stage for the second-generation 
reforms under the Punjab Government Efficiency Improvement Program (PGEIP), which seeks 
to strengthen the performance orientation of the budget, undertake pension reform to create 
additional fiscal space for social and development expenditures, improve the responsiveness of 
the civil service to public's needs, particularly in the delivery of pro-poor services; and promote 
private sector development for income generation and employment creation. 
 
2.  Likewise, the PGEIP has strong linkage with both the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
country strategy and the national poverty reduction strategy. ADB’s Pakistan country strategy 
and  program  (CSP)  for  2002–2006,1 which  was  based  on  ADB’s  poverty  assessment  for 
Pakistan in 20022 and developed in the context of the national Poverty Reduction Strategy 
Paper (PRSP), emphasized poor governance as a key cause of poverty. The CSP update 
2005–2008 further emphasized the importance of governance reforms. Poor governance not 
only resulted in poor public service delivery and greater vulnerability, but also led to a drop in 
business confidence, which in turn resulted in lower investment levels and growth. ADB’s draft 
country partnership strategy (CPS) for 2007–2011 for Pakistan maintains this focus, identifying 
governance and institutional bottlenecks as binding constraints on growth and poverty reduction. 
This is consistent with the government’s draft second-generation poverty reduction strategy, 
PRSP II, which includes effective governance and management as a key pillar.

B.   Poverty Analysis   Targeting Classification: General intervention 
Punjab’s GDP annual growth of 8% from FY2003 to FY2007 has contributed to the improvement in the poverty 
situation in Punjab. In addition, increase social spending has also improved social conditions. From a poverty head-
count ratio of 34.1% in FY2002, this decreased by 11 percentage points in FY2005. This is estimated to have further 
declined by another 2.1 percentage points in FY2007. Gains are likewise seen in some social sectors like education 
and health. The literacy rate improved from 47% in FY2002 to 62% in FY2007 while net primary enrolment rate rose 
from 45% to 70% during the same period. Infant mortality rate per 1,000 live births declined from 82 in FY2002 to 72 in 
FY2007 while child mortality rate per 1,000 live birthsa decreased from 119 to 105. The percentage of children 
between 12 and 23 months that have been fully immunized increased from 57% to 76% from FY2002 to FY2007. 
There has likewise been improvement in maternal health care during the same period with maternal mortality ratio per 
100,000 live births dropping from 350 to 257. In spite of these gains, poverty level still exceeds 20% and social 
indicators lag behind that of other comparable low income countries. Thus, reducing poverty and improving social and 
living conditions remain key tasks for the GoPb.b 
 
PRMP is a central element of the Punjab PRSP to reduce the incidence of poverty in Punjab. Subprogram 1 focused 
on the development of poverty-focused investment strategies for key social sectors, and Subprogram 2 pushed for the 
approval and operationalization of these strategies. Subprogram 1 helped to reduce the high debt service burden 
through early retirement of cash development loans and initial restructuring of provincial taxes has resulted in an 
increase in revenues. Likewise, subsidies not explicitly targeting the poor were phased out. This has created additional 
fiscal space to accommodate more PRSP-related expenditures. Subprogram 2 focused largely on improving public 
service delivery and accelerating growth through private sector development. The GoPb has implemented the MTBF 
and introduced timely, reliable and publicly accessible public accounts. It has also introduced measures to support 
sustained private sector development. The continuity of reforms in underlying systems and processes to manage 
public resources is crucial if the incidence of poverty in Punjab is to be further reduced.  
 
The PGEIP continues to support the three components of the ADB’s poverty reduction strategy: pro-poor sustainable 
economic growth, good governance, and social development. The PGEIP envisages the further improvement in the 
delivery of pro-poor social services. The implementation of the MTEF enhances the performance orientation of the 
budget, and improves its pro-poor focus. Efforts are also taken to strengthen linkages between the budget and service 
delivery in key social sectors such as health. The PGEIP also addresses the fiscal squeeze arising from pension 
liabilities by making them off-budget and creating viable pension and general provident funds. This creates additional 
fiscal space for pro-poor expenditures. Civil service reform is pursued to improve the responsiveness of the latter 
towards the needs of the public. Lastly, encouraging public-private partnerships expands the resources available for
